data.title: Add `saveFocusedPaneItem()` and call it in "core:save" command
data.body:
### Description of the Change

Add methods that chose what to save based on focus (instead of the active pane). This behavior change means that pane items in docks (#13977) will be savable too.

### Alternate Designs

The alternate we considered was having a single method which attempted to use the focused pane and then fell back to the active one, however this one was chosen because it's more predictable (i.e. doesn't depend on a state the user may not understand intuitively).

### Benefits

Editors in docks can be saved!

### Possible Drawbacks

Some may be relying on the current behavior, and use the command when an editor isn't active.

cc @nathansobo @maxbrunsfeld

data.title: Update CSS languages, autocomplete-css
data.body:
### Requirements

* Filling out the template is required. Any pull request that does not include enough information to be reviewed in a timely manner may be closed at the maintainers' discretion.
* All new code requires tests to ensure against regressions

### Description of the Change

language-less and language-sass now use the property names and values in language-css to keep the languages more in sync.  Credit goes to @Alhadis.  Some issues with Sass have been fixed as well (most notably: Sass's custom property-list syntax is now tokenized properly).
autocomplete-css now has considerably better descriptions on a good portion of the property names.

### Alternate Designs

None.

### Why Should This Be In Core?

Core packages.

### Benefits

It should be easier to propagate property name and value changes across the three CSS languages now.  No more wacky autocomplete descriptions (or at least, a lot less).

### Possible Drawbacks

There may be some Sass (not SCSS) regressions.

### Applicable Issues

None.

Will merge when green.

data.title: Snapshot `AtomEnvironment`
data.body:
This pull request is a continuation of #13916 and takes advantage of snapshots to create an `AtomEnviroment` instance as part of `script/build`. Then, at runtime, Atom can simply use this instance and complete its initialization by supplying all the information we didn't have at compile-time: setting the `ATOM_HOME`, reading the user configuration, etc.

The following is a profile of how long it takes to initialize an `AtomEnvironment` on master:

![screen shot 2017-03-17 at 16 43 10](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/482957/24050971/e1193dda-0b30-11e7-99d2-0167e460d12e.png)

After these changes, this is how the same profile looks like:

![screen shot 2017-03-17 at 16 38 51](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/482957/24050970/e0f3ad86-0b30-11e7-88ab-1807b433f6ec.png)

You can notice how creating an `AtomEnvironment` is ~2x faster now, as it went down from `~106ms` to `~58ms`.

It's worth noting that just loading the base style sheets took more than `~30ms` (more than half of the `initialize` method). This is due to performing a lot of synchronous I/O but it can be almost eliminated by, again, making use of snapshots and load as much data as possible during `script/build`. This will be addressed in a forthcoming pull request.

/cc: @atom/maintainers

data.title: Folding keybindings duplicated
data.body:
The keybinding for Fold All is `ctrl-alt-{` and for Fold Selection is `ctrl-alt-shift-[`. On a US keyboard, these are the same. I didn't override these bindings, and they remain duplicated when I start in safe mode.

Secondary problem: Under Settings => Keybindings, Fold All is shown as `ctrl-alt-{`, while in the command palette it's shown as `ctrl-alt-shift-[`. See screenshots below. Result: even on a keyboard layout that shouldn't be susceptible to this key binding duplication (on my Belgian layout, `[` and `{` don't share a physical key), Fold Selection still gets overridden by Fold All.

Keybindings according to Settings:
![2017-03-17 13_49_46-mint - vmware workstation](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/570247/24043897/212eb746-0b19-11e7-9f9b-b81464623e7d.png)

Keybindings according to Command Palette:
![2017-03-17 13_51_44-mint - vmware workstation](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/570247/24043898/212f1a88-0b19-11e7-9abe-2c18d07525e5.png)

data.title: Revert "Upgrade to Babel 6 and apply fewer transformations when transpiling babel files"
data.body:
Reverts atom/atom#13823.

For the reasons outlined by @nathansobo in https://github.com/atom/atom/pull/13823#issuecomment-287117624, we are going to revert the aforementioned pull request. Long-term we would like remove support for global transpilation but we need a safer transition path to do so, which the above pull request did not provide.

I will merge this as soon as I have a green build, and cherry pick onto beta as well in order to prevent Babel 6 from going to stable.

/cc: @atom/maintainers

data.title: Use the generated snapshot source map in `source-map-support`
data.body:
This will report the correct file and line numbers on stack traces instead of always showing `<embedded>:absoluteLineNumber`. As a result, it will also fix the `notifications` package, which will be able again to identify which package threw an exception and to create an issue on its repository.

/cc: @nathansobo @Ben3eeE

data.title: Atom not appearing on Start Menu (or anywhere) on Windows 10 after first install.
data.body:
<!--

Have you read Atom's Code of Conduct? By filing an Issue, you are expected to comply with it, including treating everyone with respect: https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md

Do you want to ask a question? Are you looking for support? The Atom message board is the best place for getting support: https://discuss.atom.io

-->

### Prerequisites

* [X ] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

Atom not appearing on Start Menu on Windows 10 after first install. Atom.exe does not exist anywhere on my system. The program, however, can be uninstalled through the control panel.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Download and install Atom
2. Acknowledge and close the welcome window
3. Go to start menu and wonder why Atom is not there
5. Go to C:\users\me\ .atom\ and wonder why atom.exe is not there
6. Go to C:\Program Files (x86)\ and wonder why atom.exe is not there
7. Go to Control Panel >> uninstall a program, and wonder why atom.exe is there
8. Restart computer
9. Repeat steps 3 through 7

**Expected behavior:** Atom in start menu.

**Actual behavior:** Atom not in start menu.

**Reproduces how often:** 100%

### Versions

atom does not work on command line. Latest version of Atom installed on 15 March 2017.

### Additional Information

I'm using a 2 month old laptop with minimal bloatware. The machine seems to be in pretty good shape.

data.title: More reliable way of stopping Babel stderr output on Windows
data.body:
The debug module used by babel tends to throw stuff onto stderr and stdout when it feels like it.

This is a problem on Windows when Atom is launched from the UI and it doesn't have these attached - writing to them causes errors.

We previously had another fix in but it was quite dependent on the internals of Babel and broke. Hopefully this one lasts longer.

data.title: CSS Auto indentation not working
data.body:
### Prerequisites

* [x] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

Indentation with: {}, [], () do not work using the CSS syntax.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Create a new blank file
2. Change the langauge to Atom's default 'CSS' syntax.
3. Create a simple CSS rule

*Where '|' is the I-cursor in Atom, and the indentation setting is set to 'Tabs (4 wide)'...*

**Expected behavior:**

.cssrule'{
'''|
}

**Actual behavior:**

.cssrule'{
|
}

**Reproduces how often:**

This happens for me 100% of the time, in my normal work environment and in safe mode.

### Versions

Atom    : 1.15.0
Electron: 1.3.13
Chrome  : 52.0.2743.82
Node    : 6.5.0

### Additional Information

Auto indentation is enabled in the settings, and works for all other langauges I use.

I for some reason, have two 'CSS' languages when changing, although neither work.

![two 'CSS' languages](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/22833343/23998475/287e44ac-0a4d-11e7-928f-f811d91aa62c.png)

data.title: multi-line editing broken with new soft wrapping
data.body:
### Prerequisites

* [x] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description
![mar-15-2017 11-59-14](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/18338995/23974366/24796158-0998-11e7-96d3-ac5b4309abff.gif)

After the most recent update to 1.15.0, I noticed multi-line editing is broken when Adding selections (above or below) or Splitting into Lines when the line is longer than 500 characters and continues onto the next line ("soft-wrapped" line?). Forgive me if I am missing something simple here; I would love to hear suggestions if this is a configuration problem on my part.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Have a line of text that surpasses 500 characters, and is thus wrapped on the following line (with a dot as the line number)
2. Use Add Selection (above or below) to add a soft-wrapped line
3. Use Split into Lines to add a soft-wrapped line

**Expected behavior:** 

"Split into lines" will split into the logical "start" of each line, regardless of soft-wrapping.

"Add selection (above or below)" will use the logical "start" of each line, regardless of woft-wrapping.

**Actual behavior:** 

"Split into lines" seems to ignore the logical "start" of soft-wrapped lines and treats the continued line as the actual line of text to which the cursor is distributed (see animated gif). 

"Add selection (above or below)" uses the correct logical "start" of the next soft-wrapped line IN ADDITION TO the "start" (NOT A REAL LINE START!!!) of the continued line, which is incorrect because, after all, this is just one big "logical line", except it has been "virtually" split at the 500 char mark (see animated gif)

**Reproduces how often:** All 500+ character soft-wrapped lines are affected, I beleive

### Versions

OSX 10.10.5
$ apm --version
apm  1.15.3
npm  3.10.5
node 4.4.5 x64
python 2.7.12
git 2.5.4
$ atom --version
Atom    : 1.15.0
Electron: 1.3.13
Chrome  : 52.0.2743.82
Node    : 6.5.0

### Additional Information

I use Atom only for Python, so not sure if this applies to other languages, etc.

data.title: Atom Autocomplete + Emmet Tab issue
data.body:
I currently have Atom installed same configuration on a Lenovo Edge 15 with Windows 10 and Ubuntu 16.04 and a 2015 Macbook Pro OSX 10.12.3. On Ubuntu, there is no issue tab expanding elements with the class or with the (example) li*3>a expand. However, on Windows 10 and OSX the tab key does not expand elements with classes or short other elements like multiple list items and anchors. 

Emmet on other editors like VScode, brackets and ST does not seem to have the problem, all the solutions I've seen have suggested adding keymapping which then causes the tab button to solely be tied to the expand emmet comment and not function as an indent anymore. 

Posting this to see if there is a possibility to get the proper team (not sure if it is an Atom or Emmet configuration issue) to work on this issue as I am sure other people feel it slows down the process of coding having to push three keys instead of one.

data.title: Compile cache files show up as inside app.asar
data.body:
<!--

Have you read Atom's Code of Conduct? By filing an Issue, you are expected to comply with it, including treating everyone with respect: https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md

Do you want to ask a question? Are you looking for support? The Atom message board is the best place for getting support: https://discuss.atom.io

-->

### Prerequisites
_Note: Impossible to test under safe mode as by definition this requires external packages._

* [ ] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

Files from packages that are compiled are showing up as being inside the `app.asar` when searching for them in the Developer Tools. The real locations only open the compiled version.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Have a third-party package installed.
2. Open Developer Tools
3. Attempt to open a file from the search (since virtually no files show up in the Sources list...)

_Note: I was seeing even stranger behavior than this, with breakpoints on package files setting themselves on internal Atom files. I deleted the `compile-cache` folder which leads me to the current better, but still very broken behavior._

**Expected behavior:** [What you expect to happen]

The file you select from the search opens the original source file, with the source map making breakpoints work.

**Actual behavior:** [What actually happens]

File "in" `app.asar` is the real file, with the source map showing which parts of the file aren't in the in-use code.
File at the real location is the compiled version of the file, when you open this it tells you there is a source map active.

Note that it is only possible to get to the real version of a package file if it has a unique name. If you try to search for a file name used in many packages (like `main.js`) then it seems to pick whichever shows up first in the list of real results.

**Reproduces how often:** [What percentage of the time does it reproduce?]

100% of the time.

### Versions

You can get this information from copy and pasting the output of `atom --version` and `apm --version` from the command line. Also, please include the OS and what version of the OS you're running.

```
> atom --version
Atom    : 1.16.0-beta0
Electron: 1.3.13
Chrome  : 52.0.2743.82
Node    : 6.5.0
> apm --version
apm  1.16.1
npm  3.10.5
node 6.9.5 x64
python 2.7.12
git 2.12.0.windows.1
visual studio 2015
```

This bug makes imposible to use this text editor.

### Versions

Latest. Can't get V number, because Atom is unresponsive.

data.title: .gitignore file not adjusting the visual aid off the Tree View
data.body:
Similar to https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/3429#issuecomment-286594653

### Description

I have downloaded atom. Installed it. Opened up a project and the `.gitignore` is not being detected and the Tree View is not changing (reducing the opacity of the folder).

It used to do this in the past. I have tried several projects and all do not work. These projects all work in other applications/IDE so I do not believe it's a project issue. I feel like I'm doing something really silly..

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Have a fresh install of Atom with no setting changes
2. Set `tree-view.hideVcsIgnoredFiles` to `true`
3. Create a new directory `~/test`
3. Change to the `~/test` directory
3. Execute `git init` within `~/test`
3. Open Atom with the command `atom ~/test`
3. Create a folder named `should-be-ignored`
4. Create a `.gitignore` file
4. Add a line containing `should-be-ignored` to the `.gitignore` file

**Expected:** Folder named `should-be-ignored` to disappear

**Actual:** Folder named `should-be-ignored` remains and does not change color

### Original Repro Steps

1. Have a fresh install of Atom with no setting changes
2. Enable the VCS settings
3. Create a folder, name it eg: `should-be-ignored`
4. Create a .gitignore, add that folder to it
5. Nothing changes

**Expected behavior:** I expect it to tint/opacity change the folder in the Tree view so it's visibly different.

**Actual behavior:** Nothing happens, no visual que.

### Versions

- Windows 10, 64bit
- Downloaded Latest atom from https://atom.io/
    - Atom 1.15.0
    - Atom Beta 1.16.0 also doesn't work

No plugins.

### Additional Information

Screenshots

![](http://i.imgur.com/sFu4nhx.png)
![](http://i.imgur.com/vvOg6jH.png)

data.title: Passing {activateItem: false} to Workspace::open causes the item not to be added to the Pane
data.body:
### Prerequisites

* [x] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

`atom.workspace.open` takes a parameter called `activateItem`, described as:

> A Boolean indicating whether to call `Pane::activateItem` on containing pane. Defaults to `true`.

While accurate, `Pane::activateItem` is responsible for calling `Pane::add`. Thus, if `activateItem` is false, the opened item does not get added to the pane at all.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Run `atom.workspace.open('file.txt', {activateItem: false})` in the Atom JS console

**Expected behavior:** [What you expect to happen]

Expect `file.txt` to be opened in a new pane item in the background

**Actual behavior:** [What actually happens]

No new item is added to the pane

**Reproduces how often:** [What percentage of the time does it reproduce?]

100%

### Versions

You can get this information from copy and pasting the output of `atom --version` and `apm --version` from the command line. Also, please include the OS and what version of the OS you're running.

```
Atom    : 1.16.0-dev-b0b1879
Electron: 1.3.13
Chrome  : 52.0.2743.82
Node    : 6.5.0
```

data.title: Lines automatically wrap after they reach a certain amount of chracters
data.body:
* [X] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

I couldn't find any reported issues on this bug which seems strange so I probably missed the issue and so I apologize before hand.

Atom V1.15.0-beta3 [fixed a bug that was causing the paste](https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/5411#issuecomment-280845675) of a large amount of characters to crash the app. This was awesome but this version also started causing lines outside of the window to wrap after they reached a certain amount of characters. So I'm guessing that there is probably a trade off — no crash on large paste = limited amount of characters per line.

Is this a bug, or is this just the way Atom works now? Is it possible to increase the amount of characters allowed per line?

### Versions

1.16.0-beta0

data.title: Merge pull request #1 from atom/master
data.body:
New Pull request

### Requirements

* Filling out the template is required. Any pull request that does not include enough information to be reviewed in a timely manner may be closed at the maintainers' discretion.
* All new code requires tests to ensure against regressions

### Description of the Change

<!--

We must be able to understand the design of your change from this description. If we can't get a good idea of what the code will be doing from the description here, the pull request may be closed at the maintainers' discretion. Keep in mind that the maintainer reviewing this PR may not be familiar with or have worked with the code here recently, so please walk us through the concepts.

-->

### Alternate Designs

<!-- Explain what other alternates were considered and why the proposed version was selected -->

### Why Should This Be In Core?

<!-- Explain why this functionality should be in atom/atom as opposed to a package -->

### Benefits

<!-- What benefits will be realized by the code change? -->

### Possible Drawbacks

<!-- What are the possible side-effects or negative impacts of the code change? -->

### Applicable Issues

<!-- Enter any applicable Issues here -->
